title: Kain panjang

  physical_appearance: This is a batik kain panjang. The main body of the kain panjang features zigzag bands of mythical animals and birds. Filler motifs are also used to decorate each band and segment
 creating an intricate and dense design. On the left
 there is a vertical panel featuring opposing triangles. In the center of the rows of triangles
 there is a vertical row of upright diamonds. The triangles and diamonds are filled with similar mythical stylised animals. There is a signature at the top-left of the batik kain panjang.

  subject_terms_1: legendary beings Peranakan birds (motifs) foliage (motif)

  subject_terms_2: Motifs Ethnic costume Peranakan (Asian people) Batik

  subject_terms_3: Peranakan costumes Batik

  sgcool_label_text: The main design feature or ‘body’ (badan) of this kain panjang is decorated with zigzag bands of mythical and fantastical animals and birds.  A variety of filler motifs are used in each decorative band.  On the broad vertical panel (kepala) of this cloth
 interlocking triangles (or tumpal) sandwich a row of upright diamonds.  Like the zigzag bands
 they are filled with curious animals and plant forms.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Djien Nio (1929-1987)
 the last in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan.  In her earlier signatures
 she used her husband’s name
 Liem Siok Hien.  But from 1965 onwards
 she used Jane Hendromartono
 combining her husband’s new Indonesian family name
 Hendromartono with Jane
 as people addressed her by.  She developed a personal style distinct from her mother and grandmother
 and experimented with a wide spectrum of colours and exotic combinations of birds
 rock formations and mythical animals.  Jane Hendromartono’s clientele expanded beyond the elite in Indonesia to include Europe
 America and Japan
 especially in the 1980s.  This piece is signed “Hendromartono’s Batik Art:” Unique Pekalongan”.

metadata.physical_appearance: This is a batik kain panjang. The main body of the kain panjang features zigzag bands of mythical animals and birds. Filler motifs are also used to decorate each band and segment, creating an intricate and dense design. On the left, there is a vertical panel featuring opposing triangles. In the center of the rows of triangles, there is a vertical row of upright diamonds. The triangles and diamonds are filled with similar mythical stylised animals. There is a signature at the top-left of the batik kain panjang.
metadata.subject_terms_2: Motifs Ethnic costume Peranakan (Asian people) Batik
metadata.sgcool_label_text: The main design feature or ‘body’ (badan) of this kain panjang is decorated with zigzag bands of mythical and fantastical animals and birds.  A variety of filler motifs are used in each decorative band.  On the broad vertical panel (kepala) of this cloth, interlocking triangles (or tumpal) sandwich a row of upright diamonds.  Like the zigzag bands, they are filled with curious animals and plant forms.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Djien Nio (1929-1987), the last in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan.  In her earlier signatures, she used her husband’s name, Liem Siok Hien.  But from 1965 onwards, she used Jane Hendromartono, combining her husband’s new Indonesian family name, Hendromartono with Jane, as people addressed her by.  She developed a personal style distinct from her mother and grandmother, and experimented with a wide spectrum of colours and exotic combinations of birds, rock formations and mythical animals.  Jane Hendromartono’s clientele expanded beyond the elite in Indonesia to include Europe, America and Japan, especially in the 1980s.  This piece is signed “Hendromartono’s Batik Art:” Unique Pekalongan”.
